Literature Review: Marine heatwaves (MHWs) have emerged as a critical concern in the field of marine ecology and climate science. These discrete periods of anomalously warm water are becoming increasingly frequent and intense, posing significant threats to marine ecosystems worldwide. This literature review aims to synthesize current knowledge on the biological impacts of MHWs and explore their implications for ecosystem services, management, and future research directions.MHWs are defined as prolonged periods of unusually high sea surface temperatures, typically lasting for days to months. Hobday et al. (2016) provided a quantitative definition of MHWs, establishing a framework for their identification and characterization. This standardization has facilitated comparative studies across different regions and time scales, enhancing our understanding of these extreme events.The increasing frequency and intensity of MHWs have been well-documented in recent years. Oliver et al. (2018) reported that the global average frequency and duration of MHWs increased by 34% and 17%, respectively, between 1925 and 2016. These trends are expected to continue under future climate change scenarios, with projections suggesting that MHWs could become 20-50 times more frequent by the end of the century (Frölicher et al., 2018).The biological impacts of MHWs are wide-ranging and can be observed at multiple levels of ecological organization. At the individual level, MHWs can cause physiological stress, reduced growth rates, and increased mortality in marine organisms. For example, Smale et al. (2019) documented widespread mortality of intertidal invertebrates during a severe MHW off the coast of Western Australia. Similarly, Hughes et al. (2017) reported extensive coral bleaching and mortality in the Great Barrier Reef following a series of MHWs.At the population level, MHWs can lead to shifts in species distributions, alterations in reproductive patterns, and changes in population dynamics. Cavole et al. (2016) described how the 2013-2015 Northeast Pacific MHW, nicknamed 'The Blob,' resulted in significant range expansions of warm-water species and contractions of cold-water species along the North American west coast. These distributional shifts can have cascading effects on ecosystem structure and functioning.Community-level impacts of MHWs are often characterized by changes in species composition, trophic interactions, and ecosystem stability. Wernberg et al. (2016) documented a regime shift from kelp forests to turf-dominated seascapes following a severe MHW off the coast of Western Australia. This shift not only altered the physical structure of the ecosystem but also had significant implications for associated biodiversity and ecosystem services.The impacts of MHWs on ecosystem services are becoming increasingly apparent. Fisheries, for instance, can be severely affected by MHWs. Mills et al. (2013) reported substantial economic losses in the Gulf of Maine lobster fishery due to a MHW-induced early season glut in 2012. Similarly, MHWs can impact coastal protection services provided by coral reefs and kelp forests, as well as carbon sequestration services offered by seagrass meadows and mangrove forests.Predicting the occurrence and impacts of future MHWs is crucial for developing effective management and adaptation strategies. Holbrook et al. (2019) reviewed current approaches to MHW prediction, highlighting the potential of both statistical and dynamical modeling techniques. However, they also noted significant challenges, including the need for improved understanding of the physical drivers of MHWs and their biological impacts.Adaptation and management approaches for MHWs are still in their infancy. Bates et al. (2019) proposed a framework for incorporating extreme events into conservation planning, emphasizing the need for flexible, adaptive management strategies. These may include the establishment of climate refugia, assisted migration of vulnerable species, and the development of early warning systems for MHWs.Despite significant advances in our understanding of MHWs and their impacts, several knowledge gaps remain. There is a need for more long-term studies to assess the cumulative effects of repeated MHWs on marine ecosystems. Additionally, research on the interactive effects of MHWs with other stressors, such as ocean acidification and pollution, is crucial for developing a comprehensive understanding of marine ecosystem responses to global change.In conclusion, MHWs represent a significant and growing threat to marine ecosystems worldwide. Their impacts span multiple levels of ecological organization and have far-reaching consequences for ecosystem services and human well-being. As the frequency and intensity of MHWs are projected to increase in the coming decades, a deeper mechanistic understanding of their biological impacts is essential. This knowledge will be crucial for developing effective prediction tools, adaptation strategies, and management approaches to safeguard marine ecosystems in the face of increasing climatic extremes.
